cab.content: SJBCRET,JA'%/&Y MINISTRY OF FOOD.lli Report for Week ending Wednesday, January 29, 1919. PART I. ACTION TAKEN. Sir John Beale, K.B.E., having resigned his position as First Secretary to theMinistry of Food, in order to take up other Government work, the Food Controller has appointed Sir William Beveridge, K.C.B., hitherto Second. Secretary, to be permanent secretary to the Ministry of Food. RESUMPTION OF EXPORT TRADE. With a view to assisting the revival of this Country's Export Trade the ministry have notified the War Trade Department that they recommend that some 40 articlesof food, or classes of foodstuffs, should be placed on the list of commodities which require to be licensed only (in effect) if exported to blockaded countries. Among thefoodstuffs so notified to the War Trade Department are the following: Tinned andPotted Meat, Meat Extract, Canned Fish (except Salmon), Saccharin and articlescontaining it, Spices of all kinds, Barley (pearled and pot), Biscuits, Cakes, PotatoFlour, Vegetables (dried and preserved), Farina, Cornflour, Macaroni, Sago and SagoFlour and Meal, Spaghetti, Starch, Tapioca and Tapioca Flour, Imported Peas andBeans, Vermicelli, Prepared Foods wholly or partially derived from Cereals (except those containing Milk), Wines. Consequent on the view expressed by the Food Council that the free export trade of Bacon, Hams and Lard should be reinstated, the Treasury raise no objection to freeexport to all destinations other than Belgium, France, and Italy, to which places, for reasons of exchange, they consider export should not be licensed. , The Food Council. Meetings of the Council were held on Thursday, January23rd, and Tuesday,. January 28th. In view of any possible dislocation in the transport services, the Council agreedto the proposal that householders should be allowed to hold stocks of flour up toone sack. It was decided to ask the Agricultural Organisation Society if they would beprepared to take over the three potato flake factories proposed to be set up in theEastern Counties. The Council agreed that the Treasury should be informed of thelarge exportable surplus of potatoes at present in this country, and should be pressed to sanction the sale in any market. It was further agreed that the matter should bebrought to the notice of the Supreme Council of Supply and Relief with a view totheir using the potatoes for relief purposes. The Council decided that further urgent representations should be made to theTreasury on the subject of the purchase of at least 11,000 tons of Argentine butter.Unless the Argentine supplies can be secured the public will be faced with theprospect of the 1 oz. ration of butter being continued during next autumn and winter.From May to August a 2 oz. ration will be rendered possible, partly by improvedhome supplies. The question whether a 2 oz. ration can be continued after Augustdepends on imports. In view of the ample stocks of condensed milk, and of the raw materials for themanufacture of margarine, the Council have agreed that control of these two com-modities. should be relaxed at an early date. In both cases, however, it is proposedto retain Orders controlling prices. In the case of margarine it is proposed: (1) That both rationing and distribution be discontinued ; (2) That the General Requisition Order be maintained ; (3) That Local Committees should retain power to redistribute local stocks ; (4) That manufacturers' licences should be maintained, and rates of purchase of raw materials be fixed by the Ministry, so long as the Ministry holds or controls stocks of raw material; (5) That the coupon be discontinued for the purchase of margarine a fortnight before control is relaxed in order that retailers may be able to estimate their requirements. A (33)7191-4 Pk 9 150 2/19 E & S . A \ T/ie Imports Board.-The Treasury have intimated that no further purchasesare to be made in the United States, of bog products, frozen and preserved meat,condensed milk and oleo oil, out of existing credits without reaffirmation by them. The following statement by the Bacon Board with reference to the stocks ofbacon and hams was submitted to the Imports Board: Stocks of bacon, February 1st - - 42,500 tons. ,, March 1st - - - - - 55,500 ,, April 1st..... 42,500 ,, ,, May 1st - - - - - - 7,500 ,, These figures are based on the assumption: (a) That 12,000 tons per week- will arrive until all the Ministry's purchases have arrived; (6) That there is no export of any further quantity, other than the amount sold to the Dutch; (c) That there is a consumption of 35,000 tons monthly. The Consumers1 Council.1 The Council met on Tuesday, January 28th. Therepresentatives of the Council entrusted with the settlement of the question of jamrationing circulated their report showing that the final agreement arrived at had beenthat jam should be retained on the coupon, but that surplus marmalade, and marmaladeonly, should be sold without the coupon. The report was received and adopted. The following resolution was moved and carried unanimously :- " That in our opinion the suggestion to permit the increasing of the fixed price of tea of any growth beyond the price of 2s. Sd. per pound is exceedingly dangerous, and should not be permitted under any circumstances without further consideration. That the raising of the fixed price in favour of China tea gives an undue advantage over British-grown produce; that discrimination in favour of one growth against others is liable to lead to fraud and confusion, and until tea is entirely free from control, the fixed price of 2s. Sd. per pound should remain for all grades and all growths." The Council approved the proposals relating to the de-control of margarine onthe understanding (1) that the quality of the margarine suffered no deterioration, and(2) that the distribution was satisfactory. Consideration of the proposals relating tothe de-control of condensed milk was postponed till the next meeting. The following resolutions by the Councils Reforms Sub-Committee were submitted: . (1) " That the Consumers' Council, recognising the good work that in the main has been done by the Ministry of Food during the war, in which, they have been glad to support those measures which seemed satisfactory to the community, considers that the continuance of its existence is even more important during the critical period we are coming to than it was during the war, and therefore declares that until all food control is abolished, the Consumers' Council should continue to exercise its functions. (2) The Council declares that for the proper continuance of its. work it is. absolutely essential that no question of general policy should be decided upon, and no definite action taken until all relevant facts are placed before the Consumers' Council, and their views ascertained. (3) That in the opinion of the Sub-Committee it would be a grave danger to the community, if, in the circumstances now existing, the powers and activities of the Ministry of Food were lessened, or if the efficiency of the Ministry were in any way diminished. (4) That the attention of the Food Controller be called to the foregoing resolutions by a deputation from the Consumers' Council." SUPPLIES AND DISTRIBUTION. Bacon and Hams-The consumption for this week is normal. No furtherpurchases have been made in the United States or Canada since the Decemberprogramme. Arrivals are a little smaller owing to the strike in New York, but stockshere are amply sufficient to meet all demands for bacon, hams, and lard. On the discovery of a tendency on the part of traders to carry smaller stocks for fear of a fall in prices, a notification was made to all the appointed importers/41 informing them that in the event of any circumstances arising which' made areduction in prices possible the Ministry would undertake either (a) to give not lessthan one montli's notice of the proposed reduction in prices to enable stockholders to clear their stocks, or (b) in the event of the Food Controller finding himself unable togive the month's notice referred to, he would undertake to make an allowance,equivalent to the reduction in price, on stocks of one ton and over, in original packages,held by the trade. A further letter was despatched to all bacon and lard wholesalersenclosing a copy of the notification circulated to the appointed importers, and calling for a return of the amount of bacon, hams, and lard held by them on Saturday,25th January. It is hoped that the above measure will encourage traders to holdlarger stocks. Cocoa. Some 2,000 tons of raw cocoa is being distributed this week as an interim allocation. Arrivals and shipments of raw cocoa continue to be very satisfactory. Condensed Milk. The demand for condensed milk in 1918 reached" a maximumin the history of the industry. The; chief causes were : - (1) Y.M.C.A. Munition Canteens, Prisoners of War Committee, Church Army and similar organisations were large buyers, as liquid milk was unsuitable for their establishments. (2) Shortage of sugar and jams. The shortage resulted in sweetened condensed milk being extensively used in domestic cooking, and otherwise in place of sugar, jam, and confectionery. (3) Female employment. Housewives of the poorer classes at work when fresh milk is delivered, purchased condensed milk for infant feeding and other uses, as it remains good in the tin for three or four days. (4) Shortage of liquid milk during 1917 and 1918. Condensed milk supple- mented supplies of liquid milk to a very considerable extent. Dried Fraits. A meeting of the Dried Fruit Advisory Committee was held on.the 28th January, when it was decided that a distribution of dried fruit should bemade as soon as possible, without waiting for further stocks to arrive. Fish. The reports on the supply of fish vary very much while in the NorthernDivisions the supplies are said to be small, in the North-Western they are well maintained ; the amount landed at Fleetwood from the 1st to the 16th of January,inclusive, was 12,927 boxes, of which 16b were prime varieties, the number of tons-allocated was approximately 802. . In the North Midland Divisions in the week ending 11th January, 119 vesselslanded 65,347 lbs. of prime fish at Grimsby, all of which was duly allocated andfetched full prices. Owing to a strike the following week no boats went out. In South Wales fish, is reported to be scarce, and the Commissioner points outthe need for more trawlers being made available with as little delay as possible. From the West of Scotland comes the report that large supplies of herrings werebeing bought at the Kyles of Bute. The average catch is said to be about 1,000 boxesa day. Margarine. Ample stocks of raw materials are landed or in sight for a period of20 weeks. British machinery is now capable of producing over 8,000 tons of margarineper week, and by June this figure will be raised to 10,500 tons per week. On theother hand the United Kingdom is not likely at present to absorb more than 7,000tons of margarine per week. The full 5 oz. ration is, in fact, not being taken up. Meat.-Such complaints as are being received at the present time are largely dueto the desire of the retailers to secure the highest class of meat, in view of theopportunity which is being given to the public to transfer their registration. It mustbe said that this opportunity has met with strong objection from the retailers. . ' Complaints, which are received regarding the supply of frozen meat to agricultural and producing areas, may be taken as evidence that the system of distribution is now on a more equitable basis than has hitherto been attained. It is frequently necessaryto point out to Farmers' Unions and similar bodies that protests against thesubstitution of imported meat for the home-grown stock of the district display a short-sighted and selfish view of the conditions affecting the whole country. In spite of the comparative shortage of home-grown meat, the supplies as a whole are proving sufficiently plentiful to permit an increase in the ration in the near future. It must'be confessed that it is very doubtful whether this increase will go intoconsumption at present prices, as, during the four weeks which ended on the 25thJanuary, the Ml amount of the existing ration was not taken up. During the current week live stock supplies are naturally being held back in anticipation of the increase in price which comes into operation at the beginning ofFebruary. Tea. All the teas which were taken out of the export sale last week have been sold. As there has been a large demand for further supplies, it has been decided tohold another sale of tea for export only, next week. ORDERS UNDER DEFENCE OF THE REALM REGULATIONS. The following Orders have been revoked : The Beehive Sections (Maximum Prices) Order, 1918. The import of honey sections is now free to traders. * . The Gooseberries Sales (England and Wales) Order, 1918, and an amending Order, dated 7 th June ; the Soft Fruit (Sales) Order, 1918 ; the Soft Fruit (Sales) (Amendment) Order, 1918 ; the Strawberries (Retail Prices) Order, 1918; the Plums (Sales) Order, 1918; the Blackberries Order, 1918; and the Damson (Sales) Order, 1918. The revocation of the above Orders abolishes control over these summer fruits,and the restrictions on their sale. The Oatmeal (Restriction) Order, 1918, which prohibited the use of oatmeal forother than human food. The Feeding of Game Order, 1917, which prohibited the feeding of game birdswith grain. ENFORCEMENT OF ORDERS. During the week ending the 11th of January, the total number of prosecutionswas 522, of which 491 resulted in convictions. The prosecutions were reported under 64 different Orders. Sentence of three months' imprisonment with hard labour was. passed at birmingham on an iron moulder. The defendant was summoned for havingapplied for, retained, and used a ration book in the name of his wife, who died inSeptember 1917. ' PART II-SUMMARY OF THE FOOD POSITION. IMPORTS. The total imports of the principal foods and feeding-stuffs in the week ended20th January (l^O320O tons) were 48 per cent, less than those of the preceding week(231,200 tons), and 35 per cent, less than the average of the first 21 weeks of the cerealyear (183,700 tons). The heaviest fall was in cereals-wheat and flour (68,000 tons as equivalent wheat)being 36 per cent., and barley, oats, and maize (8,500 tons) 62 per cent, below the21 weeks' average; no rice was entered. Bacon imports (8,600 tons).were less by17 per cent., but there were good imports of meat (14,100 tons), butter (3,900tons), and eggs (1,500 tons), as well'as apples (5,200 tons), oranges (8,100 tons), andonions (2,300 tons). * , ...... , .; r -\ A summary of the principal imports since 1st September is given in the followingtable:- Total Imports for first 21 weeks of Cereal Year. 1918. Increase or Decrease on 1917. 1918. Increase or Decrease on 1917. Quantity. Per Cent. Quantity. Per Cent.Total -Wheat Flour -Equivalent as Grain. Rico -Barley, oats, and maize. Tons. 218,400 50,500 23,500 37,000 55,400 419,300 83,200 5,600 40,000 Tons. 4 122,800 4 46,300 4 9,500 - 21,100 - 18,200 4 15,300 - 140,700 4 27,600 4 3,400 4 31,800 4- 128 4- 1,094 4 67 - 100 - 33 4- 38 - 25 4- 50 4- 155 4 390 2,222,100 4 1,022,900 4- 85 41,100 473,700 249,500 - 152,300 - 193,900 4 25,100 - 79 - 29 4- 11 CONSUMPTION. Meat. The rise of prices to producers induced a relatively large supply at thebeginning of January and supplies of home-grown meat in the second half of themonth tended to fall off. As the issues of imported meat in the. week endedJanuary 18th remained the same as in the previous week (7,500 tons) there wasa decrease in the' total supply of butchers' meat for civilian consumption in GreatBritain. Classes of meat no longer falling within the ration now represent a con-siderable quantity, estimated at 3,200 tons, and when allowance is made for wasteand losses, the estimated total consumption of rationed meat (under the higher ration of four coupons at 5d.) tends to fall below the quantity to which the public areentitled. The rate of consumption, however, varies throughout' the country, beinghigher in industrial districts and particularly in the metropolitan area. Fish. Supplies of fish at the principal inland markets have been steady duringthe past three weeks at 2,300 tons. Supplies at Billingsgate market show a tendency to fall the decrease being 5 per cent, in the week ended January 11th, followed bya further decrease of 15 per cent, in the week ended January 18th. They were also6 per cent, less than those of last year, a decrease due probably to the strike in the fishing industry in the ports supplying this market. ' STOCKS. Stocks of meat (beef, mutton and other meat) which had been rising steadily from 74,800 tons on 1st October to 137,100 tons on 1st January (Table D), have declined slightly to 134,500 tons on the 18th January, owing to a reduction of 4,100tons in the stocks of canned meat. On the other hand, stocks of canned fish haveincreased to 23,300 tons, while stocks of bacon have increased from 46,400 tons on1st, to 56,200 tons on the 18th January. Cheese stocks have fallen by 2,400 tons,and lard by 3,200 tons. Condensed milk stocks, which rose 4,000 tons between january 1st and 11th, fell 3,500 tons in the week ended January 18th, but they arestill high (34,100 tons). RETAIL PRICES. The increase in the prices of the principal foods since July 1914 as recorded bythe Department of Labour Statistics are given in Table E, the current prices showingan average increase of approximately 130 per cent. The increase in the working-classexpenditure on the same articles of food (having regard to changes in the generalconsumption of the various articles, and adjusted for" time lag ") maybe estimated at86 per cent. Applying the same method of calculation, the expenditure of the generalpopulation shows an increase of 92 per cent. The more favourable position, relatively, of the working classes would be brought out more prominently if non-controlJed and other subsidiary foods were brought into the calculation.A 7191-1B TABLE A. ' The figures for wheat and flour include stocks in port granaries and warehouses, inland warehouses,mills, and bakers' shops, as well as estimated stocks on farms; those for barley, oats, beans, and peasinclude stocks in port granaries and warehouses and in mills, in maltsters' hands, and estimated farm stocks ;those for maize, rice, and grain meals include stocks in port granaries and warehouses and in mills. The figures for sugar are stocks in possession of the Sugar Commission; those for butter, margarine,lard, cheese, condensed milk, meat, and fish include stocks at ports, in cold stores, aud in importers' andwholesalers' warehouses.
